coredata.dc:title: Atomically dispersed Co-N4 sites anchored on N-doped carbon for aqueous phase transfer hydrogenation between nitroarenes and saturated N-heterocycles

coredata.dc:description: Transfer hydrogenation reactions using non-noble metal-based nanocatalysts are extensively attractive due to their low-cost and green reaction conditions. But construction of such catalysts with maximum metal atom efficiency and high catalytic activity is still a challenging research goal. Here, atomically dispersed Co catalysts with Co-N4 active sites were fabricated, which builds a bridge for transfer hydrogenation between nitroarenes and saturated N-heterocycles in aqueous solution. The TOF value of the transfer hydrogenation reaction is much higher than nanoparticle catalyst for this reaction. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations and control experiments reveal that the excellent performance origins from the Co-N4 sites, which combines the dehydrogenation of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline with hydrogenation of nitrobenzene in one-pot. This work not only has an in-depth understanding of active sites but also shows a unique activity to the challenging, highly efficient, and green transfer hydrogenation reaction.

(e) XANES spectra at the Co K-edge of the ZnCo-ZIF, Co-N-C-700, Co-N-C-800, Co-N-C-900, CoO, Co3O4 and Co foil. (f) FT k3-weighted Ï(k)-function of the EXAFS spectra of the ZnCo-ZIF, Co-N-C-700, Co-N-C-800, Co-N-C-900, CoO, Co3O4 and Co foil. (g) Corresponding FT-EXAFS fitting curve of Co-N-C-900.
XPS analysis of (a) wide scan spectra, (b) high-resolution C1s spectra, (c) high-resolution N1s spectra, (d) high-resolution Co2p spectra in Co-N-C-700, Co-N-C-800 and Co-N-C-900 catalysts.

Transfer hydrogenation reaction of (a) Different catalysts were used to catalyze transfer hydrogenation of nitrobenzene and 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline. The bar and line charts represent the conversions of nitrobenzene and 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline, respectively. Inset shows the model reaction. (b) Cycling stability of Co-N-C-900 catalyst for the model reaction. Reaction conditions: 0.125âmmol nitrobenzene, 0.188âmmol 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline, 50âmg catalyst, 145ââ, 2âmLâH2O, 24âh, N2. Conversion and selectivity were determined by GC-MS.

Reaction energy profiles of Co-N-C-900 catalyst on Co-N4 sites for (a) the dehydrogenation of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline, (b) the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene. Selected bond distances are shown in Ã . Co atoms are shown in pink, C atoms in grey, N atoms in blue, H atoms in cyan, O atoms in orange.

head.ce:title: Atomically dispersed Co-N4 sites anchored on N-doped carbon for aqueous phase transfer hydrogenation between nitroarenes and saturated N-heterocycles

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry, Laboratory of Special Function Materials and Structure Design of the Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, PR China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry, Laboratory of Special Function Materials and Structure Design of the Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry, Laboratory of Special Function Materials and Structure Design of the Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, PR China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Transfer hydrogenation reactions using non-noble metal-based nanocatalysts are extensively attractive due to their low-cost and green reaction conditions. But construction of such catalysts with maximum metal atom efficiency and high catalytic activity is still a challenging research goal. Here, atomically dispersed Co catalysts with Co-N4 active sites were fabricated, which builds a bridge for transfer hydrogenation between nitroarenes and saturated N-heterocycles in aqueous solution. The TOF value of the transfer hydrogenation reaction is much higher than nanoparticle catalyst for this reaction. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations and control experiments reveal that the excellent performance origins from the Co-N4 sites, which combines the dehydrogenation of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline with hydrogenation of nitrobenzene in one-pot. This work not only has an in-depth understanding of active sites but also shows a unique activity to the challenging, highly efficient, and green transfer hydrogenation reaction.

ce:section.ce:para: Aromatic amines and N-heterocycles are both key intermediates in pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and other high value-added fine chemicals [1â4]. So far, many efforts have been done in synthesizing anilines and N-heterocycles, while both reduction of nitroarenes and oxidative dehydrogenation of saturated N-heterocycles systems suffer from some disadvantages (Scheme S1). For instance, various reductants [5â7], especially H2, are used for nitroarenes reduction. And catalytic hydrogenation is the mostly commonly used and atom-economic method, but high H2 pressure, high reaction temperature and complicated experimental equipment are required [8â10]. Besides, the use of other hydrogen sources always suffers from high-cost and harmful by-products problems. Unsaturated N-heterocycles are usually obtained by oxidative dehydrogenation reactions, excessive oxidants such as TBHP, sulfur, SeO2, 2-iodoxybenzoic acid (IBX), 2,3-dichloro-5,6-dicyano-1,4-benzoquinone (DDQ) and O2 are required [11â13]. Specifically, these two reactions need additional reagents and are proceeded in stricter reaction systems, which greatly increases the cost, inefficiency, and complexity of reaction process. Based on the nature of the two reactions, using nitroarenes and saturated N-heterocycles as âspecial oxidants and reductantsâ in one-pot should be a more efficient and greener path to obtain anilines and unsaturated N-heterocycles with H2O as the solvent and only by-product.

Catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH), as a safer and environmentally friendly alternative to direct hydrogenation, has attracted a lot of research interests [14â16]. The clean transformation process and moderate reaction conditions uphold the concepts of green chemistry. Great achievements have been made for the CTH reactions in recent years. Bellerâs group prepared nanoscaled Co3O4/Fe2O3 (Co3O4-NGr@C and Fe2O3/NG@C) nanoparticles (NPs) encapsulated by N-doped graphene layers for the transfer hydrogenation of nitroarenes with formic acid [17,18]. Yadong Li and co-workers synthesized a single-atom Fe catalyst stabilized on ordered mesoporous N-doped carbon (Fe1/N-C) for the transfer hydrogenation of nitroarenes with hydrazine hydrate [19]. Besides, they also prepared the Co atomic site catalyst supported on ordered porous N-doped carbon (ISAS-Co/OPNC) for transfer hydrogenation of N-heterocycles with formic acid [20]. Hai-Long Jiang et al. designed CuNi NPs confined inside MIL-101 (CuNi@MIL-101) and N-doped porous carbon wrapping Co/CoO NPs catalysts towards the hydrogenation of nitroarenes with ammonia borane dehydrogenation [21,22]. Based on these desired results, it also makes sense to set up a bridge between hydrogenation of nitroarenes and oxidative dehydrogenation of saturated N-heterocycles to simultaneously obtain anilines and unsaturated N-heterocycles in one-pot. It greatly reduces the cost and complexity of whole reaction and enhance the efficiency. Meanwhile, the CTH reaction of nitroarenes with saturated N-heterocycles as hydrogen source is almost unreported. Besides, the active components of conventional transfer hydrogenation are mainly concentrated on metal NPs [23,24], developing efficient transition metal single-atomic-site catalysts (SACs) is still facing challenges.

Since Tao Zhangâs group has successfully synthesized the Pt1/FeOx SACs and firstly proposed the concept of âsingle-atom catalysisâ [25], it has become the most promising frontier to be the bridge to connect heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysis. Diminishing the particle size to atomic level could maximize atom efficiency and improve the catalytic performance [26]. Compared with homogeneous catalysts, confining homogeneously dispersed single metal atoms on supports could obtain the advantages of excellent recyclability and stability. Recently, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), especially the Zinc-based zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF-8) has emerged as a novel branch to synthesize SACs [27â29]. The ZIF-8 has high content of N and is easily doped by various transition metal into its framework. Then the metal atoms-ligands 3D skeleton could be pyrolyzed to directly form atomic M-Nx sites. The catalyst with atomically dispersed M-Nx active sites is closely related with good catalytic activity.

Herein, we prepared atomically dispersed cobalt active sites anchored on the porous N-doped carbon and firstly applied the Co SACs to transfer hydrogenation of nitroarenes with saturated N-heterocycles. The Co SACs showed hydrophobicity, so water as the only by-product could be removed from the surface of catalysts to eliminate its influence. Meanwhile, the water as the solvent instead of organic solvents in our reaction system is also the principles of sustainable chemistry. The turnover frequency (TOF) is higher than the nanoparticle-based catalyst for this reaction. DFT results revealed that the unique and superior activity for the transfer hydrogenation reaction was attributed to the simultaneous activation of dehydrogenation and hydrogenation process on the Co-N4 sites.

Cobalt (â ¡) chloride hexahydrate (CoCl2.6H2O), Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2.6H2O) and 2-methylimidazole were purchased from Tianjin Heowns Biochem LLC. Nitroarenes and N-heterocycles were provided by Aladdin Industrial Corporation. All the chemicals were used without purification.

6.0 g Zn(NO3)2.6 H2O and 13.0 g 2-methylimidazole were dissolved in 80 mL and 160 mL methanol, respectively. These solutions were mixed followed by stirring for 24 h at room temperature. The white precipitate of ZIF-8 was collected by centrifuging, washing with ethanol and drying in vacuum. 60 mL methanol containing 600 mg ZIF-8 was dispersed under sonication for 10 min and then 10 mL methanol containing 20 mg CoCl2.6 H2O was added into the above solution, the mixture was stirred for 24 h at room temperature. The light purple crystal of ZnCo-ZIF was collected by centrifugation.

The ZnCo-ZIF was respectively pyrolyzed under N2 atmosphere at 700 â, 800 â and 900 â for 1 h, 5 â minâ1. The carbonized powder was washed with 2 M HCl at 50 â for 5 h to remove the Co NPs. Then the final powder was washed with deionized water and marked as Co-N-C-T (T: 700 â, 800 â, 900 â).

Typically, 1.164 g Co(NO3)2.6 H2O and 1.312 g 2-methylimidazole were dissolved in 100 mL methanol, respectively. These solutions were mixed followed by stirring for 24 h at room temperature. The purple precipitate of ZIF-67 was collected by centrifuging, washing with ethanol and drying in vacuum.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Catalytic transfer hydrogenation of nitrobenzene with 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline
ce:section.ce:para: The nitrobenzene (0.125 mmol), 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline (0.19 mmol), and catalyst (50 mg) were added in a sealed tube with H2O (2 mL) as the solvent. The tube was purged with a N2 balloon equipped with a needle. Then the reaction was kept at 145 â for 24 h. When the reaction was completed and cooled to room temperature, the whole reaction system was extracted by ethyl acetate. The products were analyzed by GC-MS. The recycled catalyst was washed with H2O and dried for the next use. The potassium thiocyanate (KSCN, 16 equiv. to the Co amount) was used in the poisoning test.

All of computations have been investigated using Gaussian 09 program package. The complexes geometries were optimized using the density functional theory (DFT) method based on the hybrid of Beckeâs three-parameter exchange functional and the Lee, Yang, and Parr correlation functional (B3LYP). The 6â31 G (d, p) basis set was used to calculate all atoms. Every transition state was confirmed to have only one imaginary frequency, the reactants and products were connected by transition states using intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) calculations. The binding energies of different structures could be obtained from single-point calculation by B3LYP functional.

Transmission electron microscopy (FEI Talos F200s) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Apreo S) could observe the structure of catalysts. High-resolution electron microscopy with a spherical aberration corrector (FEI, Titan Themes Cubed G2 300) could record AC HAADF-STEM images. X-ray absorption spectra was obtained from Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF) on beamline BL14W1. Data analysis and fitting were performed with the Athena, Artemis and IFEFFIT software packages [30]. Power X-ray diffraction (XRD) was analyzed on a Rigaku MiniFlex 600 diffractometer using Cu-kÎ± radiation. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PerkinElmer PHI-5702) could analyze bonding states. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was operated on a TA-Q50 TGA instrument from 20 â to 1000 â under N2. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis could obtain the specific surface area, pore volume and pore width using a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 instrument. Raman spectroscopy was obtained by a Jobin Yvon LabRAMHR800 spectrometer with 633 nm excitation wavelengths. The C, N, O contents were obtained from elemental analysis (EA, CHNS) and metal contents were determined from an inductive coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES, PQ 9000). Gas chromography (GC-2014 +AFSC, 230 C) and Gas chromography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS, Agilent 5977E) were used to analyze the conversion and selectivity of products.

The preparation method for the single Co sites catalyst was illustrated in Fig. 1a. The introduced Co2+ ions could partially replace Zn2+ and rebond with 2-methylimidazole to form bimetallic zeolitic imidazole framework (ZnCo-ZIF), which is confirmed by X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). The XANES spectra of ZnCo-ZIF is similar to ZIF-67 [31]. The Co-N scattering path at 1.54 Ã from Fourier transforms (R space), was assigned to tetrahedral coordination of Co atoms. The Co-N coordination number is 4 from EXAFS fitting (Fig. 1e-f and Table S1). Additionally, the average pore size and total pore volume (Fig. S1, Table S2) did not decrease after the introduction of Co2+. The above results indicated that Co ions were not confined in the micropores of ZIF-8, instead they partially substituted Zn nodes of the ZIF-8 to form ZnCo-ZIF. The obtained sample powders of ZIF-8, ZnCo-ZIF and ZIF-67 were shown in Fig. S2. The ZnCo-ZIF has a similar rhombic dodecahedron shape from the TEM, SEM images and XRD diffraction pattern (Fig. S3-S4) with ZIF-8. During pyrolysis of ZnCo-ZIF, Zn nodes could increase the spatial interval between Co atoms and prevent Co atoms from aggregating into Co NPs. Meanwhile, Zn atoms would volatilize away and create free N sites. The TGA analysis of ZnCo-ZIF was shown in Fig. S5. The weight loss of 2.3% at 371.8 â resulted from the water adsorbed on the surface of ZnCo-ZIF. The weight loss between 400 â and 600 â was ascribed to the decomposition of organic linker. When the pyrolysis temperature rises from 700 to 900 â, the evaporation of Zn nodes would generate the N-rich defects. Adjacent Co atoms easily occupied these defective sites and coordinated with N atoms, which avoids the aggregation of cobalt atoms. So no Co NPs were observed in the Co-N-C-700, Co-N-C-800 and Co-N-C-900 catalysts (Fig. S6). A hollow morphology of Co-N-C-900 catalyst could be observed. The reason is probably that Co nodes on the surface of ZnCo-ZIF are non-volatile, which could capture nitrogen or carbon species in the pyrolysis process. The inner nitrogen and carbon species migrated to the surface and a hollow structure was formed. The hollow morphology was more obvious at higher pyrolysis temperature. The element mapping images in Fig. 1b, d showed the highly dispersed Co, N and C of Co-N-C-900 and the Co content is 1.12% from ICP (Table S3). The high density of Co SAs (yellow circle spots) was observed by the aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM (Fig. 1c). XANES shows that the Co K absorption edges of Co-N-C-700, Co-N-C-800 and Co-N-C-900 are between CoO and Co3O4, indicating that the valence of Co is between Co2+ and Co3+. Compared with ZnCo-ZIF, the Co-N scattering paths of Co-N-C-T catalysts shift to a low R-position of 1.41 Ã , showing a slight change of the Co coordination mode. The Co-Co and Co-O coordination peaks were not observed, confirming that Co-N-C-T catalysts have an atomic dispersion state after pyrolysis. From the fitting results, the Co atom is coordinated by four N atoms, with a Co-N4 configuration (Fig. 1e-g and Table S1).

The wetting experiments were performed to study the relationship between the structure properties and catalytic activities. The water contact angles (WCA) increase from 120Â°, 125Â° to 136Â° with the increase of pyrolysis temperature, indicating the increased hydrophobic properties of the Co-N-C-T catalysts (Fig. S7a-c). The hydrophilic groups are not existed in the Co-N-C-900 catalyst from FT-IR (Fig. S8) due to most functional groups were carbonized and volatilized after pyrolysis. According to the Wenzelâs theory [32], the rough surface structure has an influence on the superhydrophobic property. As can be seen from the SEM image of Co-N-C-900 catalyst (Fig. S9), abundant nano-globules are distributed on the surface of the catalyst, leading to the rough catalyst surface. Moreover, these nano-globules could form a number of deep trenches, which could trap air inside to form many air cushions. When the catalyst is in contact with water, the gas-liquid interface was significantly increased by the air cushions. Based on these results, the Co-N-C-900 catalyst shows hydrophobic property. It is also reported that the release of gas also leads to the superhydrophobic property of the catalyst [33]. To study the role of Zn atoms, the nitrogen doped carbon layer encapsulated Co NPs catalyst (Co@NC-900) was prepared by directly pyrolyzing ZIF-67. The Co@NC-900 catalyst showed type â £ curve with H1 hystereis loop, suggesting the typical mesoporous structure (Fig. S10a-b). In the absence of Zn atoms, the adjacent Co nodes tend to aggregate during the pyrolysis due to the obviously decreased space distance. Therefore, the average size of Co NPs is 13.7ânm (Fig. S11). The water contact angle of Co@NC-900 is 97Â° (Fig. S7d), showing the poor hydrophobicity. Accordingly, three diffraction peaks in Fig. S12 could be observed at 2Î¸=â44.2, 51.5 and 75.7Â°, assigned to the (111), (200) and (220) planes of metallic Co (JCPDS No. 15-806).

The ZnCo-ZIF precursor was completely carbonized from 700ââ to 900ââ, supported by the characteristic peaks at 25Â° and 43Â° for (002) and (101) planes of graphitic carbon (Fig. S13) [34]. And diffraction peaks of Co NPs were not observed, which is consistent with the HAADF-STEM results. Compared with Co-N-C-700 (ID/IG=1.00), Co-N-C-800 (ID/IG=1.09) and Co-N-C-900 (ID/IG=1.07) catalysts have more defects from Raman analysis (Fig. S14). After pyrolysis of ZnCo-ZIF at high temperatures, Co-N-C-T catalysts show the characteristics of microporosity (Fig. S15a-b). The surface areas of Co-N-C-T catalysts are decreased compared with the ZIF-8 and ZnCo-ZIF (Table S2). The reason is probably that the origin skeleton of ZnCo-ZIF was changed during the transformation of ligands to graphitic carbon materials. New micropores were formed at high pyrolysis temperatures. High surface area, internal cavity, abundant micropores and highly distributed Co SAs jointly promote mass transfer and facilitate the complete exposure of active sites.

XPS analysis showed that C, N, Co elements are existed in the catalysts ( Fig. 2a). The C1s spectra were divided into C-C (284.6âeV), C-N (285.3âeV), C-O (286.4âeV) and O-CO (288.6âeV) [35], the C-N bond confirmed that N atoms were successfully doped in the carbon skeletons (Fig. 2b). In the Co2p high-resolution spectra (Fig. 2d), the Co2p1/2 and Co2p3/2 at 796.6âeV and 781.4âeV are characteristic peaks of Co2+, the Co2p1/2 and Co2p3/2 at 795.5âeV and 780.0âeV are ascribed to Co3+. The valence state of Co is in good agreement with the XAS analysis. The peaks at 784.5 and 802.7âeV are satellite peaks [34]. The N1s spectra includes Pyridinic N (398.8âeV), Pyrrolic N (399.8âeV) and Graphitic N (401.2âeV). It is generally accepted that Pyridinic N acts as metal-coordinated site (Fig. 2c) [31,35,36].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Catalytic evaluations towards transfer hydrogenation reaction
ce:section.ce:para: To study the factors that affect the activities of the catalyst, the transfer hydrogenation reaction of nitrobenzene and 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline was performed as a benchmark reaction. The 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline serves as the hydrogen source to convert nitrobenzene to aniline, water is generated as the only by-product. And water was also used as the green solvent in whole reactions to replace the traditional organic solvents. On basis of the water contact angles, the catalysts with different pyrolysis temperatures have strong hydrophobic abilities. Due to the repulsion of water solvent, the hydrophobic substrates easily get access to the active sites and the by-product water is easily desorbed from the catalyst surface, decreasing the mass transfer impedance, and improving the catalysis efficiency. In addition, the micropore structure and high surface area of the Co-N-C-T catalysts provide the channels for mass transfer, nitrobenzene is easy to diffuse to Co-N4 single sites and hydrogenated into aniline. The catalytic performances of different catalysts are assessed in Fig. 3a. The Co-N-C-T catalysts all showed high activities and Co-N-C-900 catalyst had best catalytic activity with 98% nitrobenzene conversion and 99% 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline conversion. Since a long needle is used to blow N2 into the tube to exhaust air, while there is still a small amount of air was remained in the tube. Both air and nitrobenzene are hydrogen acceptors, the air in the tube would compete with nitrobenzene for the hydrogen source. The reaction was performed under air, which showed that only 34% of nitrobenzene was hydrogenated while the conversion of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline was 87%. Therefore, the conversion of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline is higher than that of nitrobenzene. When ZIF-8 and ZnCo-ZIF catalyzed the reaction, only 1% and 8% of nitrobenzene were converted, 20% and 18% of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline were converted due to the remaining air in the tube. 11% conversion of nitrobenzene and 15% conversion of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline were obtained by NC-900, the catalyst was prepared from the direct pyrolysis of ZIF-8. The nitrobenzene was hardly hydrogenated without catalyst. For the Co@NC-900 catalyst, the mesoporous structure facilitates the mass transfer and substrates could reach the active sites through the abundant mesopores in the process of catalysis. Furthermore, the mesopores could serve as reservoirs for reactants to improve the activity. Therefore, the Co@NC-900 catalyst had high conversions, while it had a higher Co content of 43.80% and large Co NPs. So Zn nodes in the catalyst precursor play a key role to prepare the single sites catalyst.

Moreover, the TOF of Co-N-C-900 (0.532âhâ1) is much higher than that of Co@NC-900 (0.0119âhâ1) and reported Ni@NCF-700 (0.0558âhâ1) catalysts for this reaction [37]. The Co-N-C-900 single-atom catalyst shows superior activity than Co@NC-900 catalyst due to the following reasons. (1) The metal atom utilization of Co-N-C-900 catalyst is close to 100%, while the Co@NC-900 catalyst is thermodynamically unstable and prone to migration and coalescence during catalysis due to the high surface energy of metal NPs. (2) The active sites of Co-N-C-900 catalyst are fully exposed to the substrate, the outer N-doped carbon shell of Co@NC-900 catalyst greatly increases the mass transfer limitation. (3) The surface area of Co@NC-900 catalyst is 211âm2gâ1, which is much lower than that of Co-N-C-900 catalyst (782âm2gâ1). The SCN- could coordinate with Co cations to form a stable chelate, so the SCN- was used to poison the Co-N4 sites of Co-N-C-900. The conversion of nitrobenzene was only 2% by the Co-free sites, indicating that Co-N4 single sites are the active sites in catalysis. In order to study the competitive adsorption of nitrobenzene and 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline on the single-atom sites, the controlled experiments were performed in Table S4, when the molar ratio of nitrobenzene and 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline increased from 1:1â1:1.2, the conversions of nitrobenzene are nearly constant. The low conversion of nitrobenzene and high conversion of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline resulted from the small amount of hydrogen source (Table S4 , entries 1â2). Further increasing the molar ratio of nitrobenzene and 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline to 1:1.5 and 1:1.8, the conversion of nitrobenzene was increased slightly. The increased conversion of nitrobenzene results from the increased amount of hydrogen source (Table S4 , entries 3â4). It is concluded that when the molar amount of nitrobenzene remains constant, adjusting the molar amount of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline has no significant effect on the reaction. Therefore, the nitrobenzene and 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline donât present competitive adsorption on the single-atom sites. Besides, we have carried out the hydrogenation reaction of nitrobenzene in H2 and dehydrogenation reaction of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline in N2, the reaction results and conditions are listed in Table S5. Under the same reaction conditions, the conversion of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline (66.6%) is higher than that of nitrobenzene (16.3%), indicating that the dehydrogenation of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline is easier than the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene and likely to be the rate determining step in the one-pot reaction.

The reusability of the Co-N-C-900 catalyst was also evaluated (Fig. 3b). The catalyst was reused for eight cycles and maintained a conversion over 90%. The decreased activity could be attributed to the loss of catalyst during the recycling process. No Co NPs were observed from Co-N-C-900 catalyst after eight cycles (Fig. S16a) and the Co content of recycled Co-N-C-900 is decreased by only 0.02% (Table S3). The diffraction peaks of Co NPs were also not observed in Fig. S16b. And the valence state of Co in the recycled Co-N-C-900 catalyst was nearly unchanged after eight cycles (Fig. S17). While the conversion of Co@CN-900 was dramatically decreased by 62% after three cycles (Fig. S18). From TEM image of Co@CN-900 catalyst, the Co NPs had an obvious aggregation and the average size of Co NPs was 16.0ânm (Fig. S19a-b). Besides, the content of Co was decreased from 43.8% to 22.0% (Table S3). All of these results suggest that the Co-N-C-900 catalyst has high stability.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Catalytic applications towards transfer hydrogenation of nitroarenes and saturated N-heterocycles
ce:section.ce:para: The nitroarenes underwent the transfer hydrogenation reaction to confirm the scope of the Co-N-C-900 catalyst ( Table 1). The meta-substituent has an inductive effect, which could disperse the charge density of the nitro N atom and contribute to the hydrogenation of the nitro groups. So the 3-nitrotoluene had higher conversion than that of 1-methyl-4-nitrobenzene (Table 1, entries 2â3). The 4-nitrobenzaldehyde was converted into 4-aminobenzaldehyde due to the electron-withdrawing effect of -CHO group (Table 1, entry 4). The -CHO group was not hydrogenated into -CH2OH group, indicating that the catalyst has desirable functional group tolerance and high selectivity. The ortho and para substituents have a conjugation effect, increasing the electron density of the N atom, which is not conductive to the reduction of nitro groups. So the conversion of the 3-bromonitrobenzene was higher than the 1-bromo-4-nitrobenzene and 2-bromonitrobenzene (Table 1, entries 5â7). Only 65% of 1,4-difluoro-2-nitrobenzene was converted, probably due to the steric hindered effect of two substituents (Table 1, entry 8). The 1-chloro-4-nitrobenzene and 1-chloro-3-nitrobenzene gave the expected conversions to the corresponding aniline products (Table 1, entries 9â10). The 1-chloro-2-nitrobenzene gave the moderate conversion of 82% (Table 1, entry 11). Only one of the nitro groups was hydrogenated with 2,4-dinitroaniline as the reactant, 3 equivalents of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline relative to the substrate were added (Table 1, entry 12). The conversion of 3-nitroaniline was higher than that of the 2-nitroaniline and 4- nitroaniline due to the conjugation effect (Table 1, entries 13â15). Due to the existence of two electron donors and steric hindrance effect, the conversion of 2-mythyl-3-nitroaniline was only 60% (Table 1, entry 16).

The general applicability of the Co-N-C-900 catalyst was also verified for the transfer hydrogenation of nitrobenzene with various saturated N-heterocycles. Firstly, 60% of the aniline was obtained, the isoquinoline and 3,4-dihydroisoquinoline were produced with conversions of 70% and 29% ( Table 2, entry 2). The reduction of 1-methyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline produced 76% 1-methylisoquinoline and 2% 3,4-dihydro-1-methylisoquinoline, the conversion of nitrobenzene was 46% (Table 2, entry 3). The indoline was dehydrogenated into indole with 95% conversion and the conversion of nitrobenzene reached 51% (Table 2, entry 4). The 2-methylindole was observed with 99% conversion and 53% of aniline was obtained (Table 2, entry 5).

The transfer hydrogenation reactions between the halogenated-nitrobenzene and saturated N-heterocycles were also performed to investigate the dehalogenation phenomenon ( Table 3). Due to the steric hindrance effect, the 1-chloro-4-nitrobenzene showed the higher conversion than 1-chloro-2-nitrobenzene with 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline and 1-methyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline as the hydrogen sources (Table 3, entries 1â4). The 3-bromonitrobenzene and 1-methyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline showed high conversions (> 80%) due to the inductive effect (Table 3, entry 5). The 1-fluoro-2-nitrobenzene and 1,4-difluoro-2-nitrobenzene had moderated conversions reacting with 1-methyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline (Table 3, entries 6â7). The dehalogenation products were not detected in these reactions. Therefore, the Co-N-C-900 catalyst showed wide applicability and high selectivity towards the transfer hydrogenation between various nitrobenzene derivatives and saturated N-heterocycles.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Mechanism study of the transfer hydrogenation of nitrobenzene and 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline
ce:section.ce:para:
DFT calculations were performed to study the reaction mechanisms of transfer hydrogenation reaction catalyzed by Co-N-C-900 catalyst. Firstly, the Co atom in Co-N4 as active sites to activate 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline is discussed (
Fig. 4a). A Co-H bond is firstly formed with the bond distance of 2.77âÃ (IM1). Then the H atom is transferred from 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline to Co site via transition state TS1 with a Co-H distance of 1.43âÃ (IM2). Subsequently, the H atom (on the carbon adjacent to the N atom) is transferred to the N atom via transition state TS2 with an energy carrier of 2.11âeV, indicating that the formation of a new N-H bond (IM3) is the rate determining step. The H-H bond of 1.96âÃ between 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline and catalyst is formed via transition state TS3 and 3,4-dihydroquinoline is obtained (IM4) with the release of one molecule H2. Then the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene is triggered. Isomerization of 3,4-dihydroquinoline afforded 1,2-dihydroquinoline (IM5). Trace amounts of 3,4-dihydroquinoline could be detected by GC-MS. A similar dehydrogenation process is performed with 1,2-dihydroquinoline as the benchmark. The H atom on N atom interacts with Co site (TS4) and a new Co-H bond of 1.43âÃ (IM6) is formed. Then the H atom of C atom is transferred to the N atom via transition state TS5 with an energy carrier of 1.83âeV. The hydrogen transfer process is also a rate-determining step. The H atoms from Co-H bond and N-H bond interact with each other (IM7). Finally, a molecule of hydrogen is released via transition state TS6 and objective quinoline is obtained (IM8) [38â40].

Under hydrogen atmosphere, the process of nitrobenzene to aniline catalyzed by Co-N-C-900 catalyst was proposed in Fig. 4b. The nitrobenzene is generally reduced via two main reaction paths, the âdirect pathâ and âcondensation pathâ [41â43]. There are three intermediates of azoxybenzene, azobenzene and hydrazobenzene in the condensation path. The hydrogenation of azobenzene catalyzed by Co-N-C-900 catalyst was conducted out to study the pathway of our catalytic system. While aniline was not formed, indicating that the reduction over Co-N-C-900 catalyst proceeds via direct path. In the reduction process, the nitrobenzene and hydrogen are firstly activated by catalyst (IM1). The H2 molecule is adsorbed on the Co atom of the catalyst and dissociates to generate metal hydrides. Then hydrogen spillover from Co atom to the Pyridinic N atoms occurs [44] and a N-H bond is formed on N-doped carbon shell (TS1). The formed H atom attacks one of O atom in the nitro-group to form *Ph-NOOH intermediate (IM2). Then another O atom is activated (IM3) by overcoming a low activation barrier (TS2). The O atom is attacked by H atom to form *PhN(OH)2 intermediate (IM4). Another molecule of hydrogen is dissociated with the help of catalyst (IM5). Next, the H atom binds with one of -OH groups to form *PhNOH(OH2) intermediate (IM6), which is the rate-determining step of reduction reaction (TS3) due to the highest energy barrier of 5.24âeV (Fig. S23). The N-O bond is dissociated to form *PhNHOH intermediate with a molecule of H2O generated (IM7). The H atom bonds to the remaining -OH group to form *PhNH(OH2) intermediate (IM8). Finally, the aniline is obtained with the dissociation of N-O bond and the generation of H2O (IM9) [41,43,45]. Seen from above analysis, we conclude that the mechanism of transfer hydrogenation is that H2 is firstly generated from dehydrogenation of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline and the H2 acts as hydrogen source to reduce nitrobenzene. The two steps are both catalyzed by the Co-N4 sites of Co-N-C-900 catalyst and H2O is the only by-product. The formed H2O molecules could easily escape from the catalyst due to the hydrophobic properties of Co-N-C-900 catalyst. Besides, several studies have made comparisons between single atom and nanoparticles catalysts for hydrogenation of nitrobenzene via DFT calculations [41,46], showing that the reaction energies for metal nanoparticles are significantly higher than that of single atom catalysts. Therefore, the single atom catalysts had superior activity than nanoparticles catalyst for the hydrogenation reactions.

In summary, the atomically dispersed Co catalysts were prepared via pyrolysis of bimetallic ZIF precursors. The Co-N4 coordination structure was confirmed by AC HAADF-STEM and XAFS. The obtained catalysts were used for the one-pot transfer hydrogenation of nitroarenes with saturated N-heterocycles in aqueous solution, which complies with the concepts of green and sustainable chemistry. The hydrophobicity of the catalyst facilitates high adhesion of organic substrates and remove the by-product water from the surface of catalyst. The activity of Co-N-C-900 is much higher than NPs-based catalyst for this reaction. Moreover, the DFT calculations shows strong interactions between Co-N4 sites and substrates, which facilitates the transfer of hydrogen from 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline to nitrobenzene. The relevant reaction mechanisms were also rationally proposed. This study should broaden the application of SACs in heterogeneous catalysis.

Dan Xu: Conceptualization, Investigation, Data curation, Formal analysis, Writing â original draft. Ruirui Liu: Methodology, Software, Resources. Jianfeng Li: Formal analysis. Huacheng Zhao: Investigation. Jiantai Ma: Supervision, Funding acquisition. Zhengping Dong: Supervision, Project administration, Writing â review & editing.
